image.altText: Angus Campbell in uniform speaks at a lectern against a black background

items.synopsis: Defence Chief Angus Campbell launches an attempt to remove awards from those who held command positions in the Afghanistan war.

title.children: Fresh push to revoke Afghanistan medals following Brereton war crimes inquiry

image.altText: Rolf Harris

items.synopsis: Rolf Harris, the disgraced Australian entertainer who was convicted in 2014 of sexual offences against girls and young women, died nearly two weeks ago, but the details have only just been made public.

title.children: Family kept Rolf Harris's death a secret for almost two weeks

image.altText: Someone walks past a Melbourne house.

items.synopsis: There are fears landlords will pass on the cost of a new land tax introduced in the Victorian state budget onto renters, a concern the treasurer has rejected as "specious logic".

title.children: Concerns Victoria's new land tax could cause more pain for renters caught in tightening market

image.altText: Tim Pallas in profile on budget day

items.synopsis: Victoria's budget targets a group of people many may view unsympathetically, and the government's calculating they will complain about it, then pay up, writes Daniel Ziffer.

title.children: Victoria's budget takes an almost aggressive approach to reclaim revenue, and it's not without risk

image.altText: A map of Victoria with red, blue and green tabs saying winner, loser, neutral.

items.synopsis: See how the Victorian government prioritised spending in its post-election budget.

title.children: New taxes for big business, more hospitals: The winners and losers of the Victorian budget

image.altText: Xi Jinping raises his glass and proposes a toast while standing behind a lecturn in front of Chinese flags.

items.synopsis: While the leaders of the G7 met in Japan, Chinese President Xi Jinping used a China-Central Asia Summit to push further economic and trade ties along the old Silk Road under the banner of his signature policy — the Belt and Road Initiative. So how is the project tracking and can it challenge US global influence?

title.children: Xi Jinping's Belt and Road Initiative has cost more than $1 trillion already — what has that much money bought?

image.altText: A close up of Dianne Feinstein

items.synopsis: Dianne Feinstein is one of just two senators representing the 40 million people of California. But at 89 and struggling with poor health, many Democrats are asking if she's up to the job.

title.children: One of the most powerful women in America is ill and seemingly confused. Should she step down?

image.altText: Jenny, dressed in a green and blue knitted top, stands in the kitchen and holds a mobile phone to her ear.

items.synopsis: Over a four-hour phone call, scammers gained access to Jenny's computer and transferred $300,000 out of her account. By the time she alerted the bank, it was too late.

title.children: Jenny lost $300,000 to a complicated scam, but her bank didn't notice until it was too late

image.altText: A composite showing the same street, on the left with a road driving down a car and on the right a person on a bike path.

items.synopsis: From using AI to create more beautiful versions of existing streets to harnessing machine learning to help cities respond to climate change, emerging technology is helping shape the future of our public spaces.

title.children: This artist uses AI to turn our streets into 'a place you'd rather live'. But experts say it could actually help our cities adapt to climate change

image.altText: A teleprompter stands in the foreground as a man stands at a podium

items.synopsis: The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation warns right-wing extremists are trying to recruit more people.

title.children: 'Awful but lawful': Neo-Nazi groups becoming more emboldened, ASIO boss warns

image.altText: A four-storey building with large glass windows wrapping around it and brick for the first floor sits under a grey and dark sky.

items.synopsis: Geelong council will permanently cease referring to January 26 as Australia Day, as part of a series of changes to how the city commemorates the contentious date.

title.children: Geelong City Council scraps Australia Day celebrations in unanimous vote about January 26

image.altText: An illustration of a hot pink pill with blue and black liquid pouring out

items.synopsis: A new kind of ADHD clinic is cashing in on surging demand for diagnoses — and promising salaries of more than $900,000 to recruit psychiatrists.

title.children: 'I thought it was a typo': Patients charged up to $3,000, doctors offered $900,000 salaries to work online in ADHD diagnosis explosion

image.altText: Meta logo in background in focus with blurry silhouette heads in foreground.

items.synopsis: Facebook parent company Meta sells animated graphics company Giphy at a major loss after the UK competition regulator ordered it to divest the startup over competition concerns.

title.children: UK watchdog forces Meta to sell Giphy, resulting in multi-million-dollar loss

image.altText: A white airplane with the blue and red logo of Air France is pictured from inside the airport Paris Charles de Gaulle.

items.synopsis: France formally bans domestic flights on short routes that can be covered by train in less than two-and-a-half hours — a move aimed at reducing airline emissions.

title.children: France bans short-haul domestic flights that could be made by train

image.altText: A blonde woman in an orange sweater stands behind a cafe counter top.

items.synopsis: Renee Johnstone's Saturday trade usually covers her cafe's grocery bill for the following week. She and other business owners are fed up with what they say is a lack of accountability from energy providers.

title.children: Renee just lost $6,500 because of a power outage and she is demanding consequences

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers delivers the budget speech.

items.synopsis: Rather than making inflation worse, it seems that by cutting prices for many of us, the budget will help bring down inflation sooner, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Will the federal budget throw fire on Australia's inflation crisis?

image.altText: A woman stands in front of a window with a sheer curtain, in shadow

items.synopsis: Becoming homeless has meant "Joanne" and her kids have lived in six hotels, two shelters and one caravan park in three years. Her family is part of an increasing number of people struggling to find shelter in Tasmania.

title.children: Buying food from servos and no room for toys, life for a homeless mum and kids living in hotels is a struggle

image.altText: A car is ablaze in the middle of a road at night.

items.synopsis: Several dozen youths pelted police with objects and set cars and bins alight on Monday night following the death of two boys aged 15 and 16 in an e-bike crash.

title.children: Welsh police face questions over road deaths that sparked Cardiff riot

image.altText: Large crowd, generic image, good for population stories.

items.synopsis: One in six migrants are paid less than the national minimum wage and the exploitation is also undercutting local workers, according to a new report by the Grattan Institute.

title.children: 'Racism, discrimination and confiscated passports'. This is not a third world problem. This is common among migrants in Australia

image.altText: A young woman sitting in a car.

items.synopsis: Despite relying on medicinal cannabis to ease pain caused by chronic illness, Imogen fears the drug could get her in legal strife on the road.

title.children: Imogen is scared she'll lose her licence for driving after taking her prescribed meds

image.altText: Crew stand on the top of a submarine.

items.synopsis: Almost 700 complaints about unacceptable behaviour — including sexual misconduct, bullying and harassment — have been reported within the Royal Australian Navy Fleet Command in the past two years.

title.children: Hundreds of misconduct complaints within Australian navy over two-year period, with most senior ranks involved

image.altText: David Hurley

items.synopsis: Governor-General David Hurley's daughter's wedding reception was held at Government House on March 11, 2023. Yesterday, his office told a Senate estimates hearing he was entitled to use his official Canberra residence as the venue.

title.children: Office of Governor-General says no rules broken hosting daughter's wedding reception at Government House

image.altText: Police shine a flashlight at a young person who is sitting on the ground with their hands raised

items.synopsis: In a new half-hour film designed to show the challenges of policing youth offenders, more than 20 shots of children appear in handcuffs. Critics say using this level of force is excessive.

title.children: Queensland police released a film showing how tough they are on youth crime. Advocates worry about what's in it

image.altText: An aerial view of rows of seated graduation students with colourful sashes over their black academic robes.

items.synopsis: More than 3 million Australians will have their HECS-HELP debts indexed at 7.1 per cent come June 1.

title.children: Thinking of paying off your HECS debt before indexation? The ATO says you better do it tomorrow

image.altText: A basketballer with his partner on the Port Adelaide waterfront.

items.synopsis: A decade after Alex Starling moved to Australia to pursue an AFL career, the American has fulfilled a very different sporting dream — joining the NBL with the Adelaide 36ers on the same day as he became an Australian citizen.

title.children: After a dalliance with the AFL, Florida-born Starling becomes a citizen and a 36er on same day

image.altText: Madeleine McCann

items.synopsis: German prosecutors confirm the search is taking place but say they can not give further details "for tactical investigative reasons".

title.children: Police and sniffer dogs continue search for Madeleine McCann at Portuguese dam

image.altText: Two women sitting next to each other and laughing.

items.synopsis: Lisa Messenger sold her house and pushed her body to its limits trying to conceive. In one phone call, her best friend Sarah Megginson changed her life with a "phenomenal" gift.

title.children: Lisa spent eight years and $500,000 on IVF. Then her best friend made a 'miracle' possible

image.altText: Several bags of the drug ice on the ground

items.synopsis: Three hundred kilograms of methamphetamine was drilled out of a cargo shipment in Sydney in what police say was the work of a well-funded syndicate.

title.children: Federal police hunting crime syndicate behind elaborate $270 million Sydney ice bust

image.altText: Paul Kelly smiles widely with bright lights behind him. The top of his guitar can be seen in his hands.

items.synopsis: The beloved Australian musician argues poetry is not something to be afraid of. Rather, Kelly reckons it might change your life.

title.children: Paul Kelly says the thing that 'heightens life' might be passing us by

image.altText: Boris Johns grins and squints as he leaves 10 Downing Street.

items.synopsis: Former British prime minister Boris Johnson has been referred to police by the government's Cabinet Office over new allegations he broke lockdown rules during the COVID-19 pandemic, according to reports.

title.children: Boris Johnson referred to police over new allegations of lockdown breaches

image.altText: Tim Pallas gestures with his hand as he delivers a speech inside in front of a red backdrop.

items.synopsis: Big businesses, holiday-home owners and landlords will be asked to foot the bill for the Victorian government's COVID-19 debt, as part of a 10-year budget repair plan unveiled in the state budget.

title.children: Victorian budget targets big employers and property investors with 'COVID Debt Levy'

image.altText: A man looks to his left as he buttons his suit jacket

items.synopsis: Prince Harry has lost the bid to legally challenge the British government who won't let him pay for police protection.

title.children: British government won't let Prince Harry pay for police protection when in UK

image.altText: A woman, wearing a jumper that says Always Was, Always Will Be, smiling.

items.synopsis: First Nations elders call on the New South Wales government to release an independent report into the reburial of 42,000-year-old Mungo Man and Mungo Lady — Australia's oldest known human remains.

title.children: One year after Mungo Man and Mungo Lady's controversial reburial, Indigenous elders want answers

image.altText: President Joe Biden speaks about the evacuation of American citizens.

items.synopsis: The ASX loses ground and US stocks slip as little progress is made between Democrats and Republicans over lifting the US government's borrowing limit. Follow the day's events, with insights from our business reporters, on the live markets blog.

title.children: ASX falls after Wall Street lost ground and US debt negotiations dragged on

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has slipped this morning after there was no progress in talks overnight in Washington to lift the US government's $US31.4 trillion borrowing limit. Nearly all sectors are lower on the ASX 200 today. Among them banks, technology, and miners. Only oil stocks are higher after oil prices rose overnight on concerns about tightening supply. Online travel agency Webjet (+5.6 per cent) surged after revenue more than doubled over the year as demand for travel rebounds from the pandemic.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX movers and shakers

children.content: The Australian share market has slipped this morning after there was no progress in talks overnight in Washington to lift the US government's $US31.4 trillion borrowing limit.
Nearly all sectors are lower on the ASX 200 today.
Among them banks, technology, and miners.
Only oil stocks are higher after oil prices rose overnight on concerns about tightening supply.
Online travel agency Webjet (+5.6 per cent) surged after revenue more than doubled over the year as demand for travel rebounds from the pandemic.

props.alt: Best and worst performers on ASX 200 index

children.content: ASX movers
(Refinitiv)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is lower in early trade after Wall Street slumped amid stalled US debt negotiations in the US. The ASX 200 index has lost 0.4 per cent, with most sectors in the red led down by healthcare, academic firms and consumer stocks. Miners and banks are also weighing on the market. Gold miner Bellevue Gold (+2.8 per cent) is doing the best, while artificial intelligence firm BrainChip Holdings (-3.6 per cent) is having another bad day.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian shares open in the red

children.content: The Australian share market is lower in early trade after Wall Street slumped amid stalled US debt negotiations in the US.
The ASX 200 index has lost 0.4 per cent, with most sectors in the red led down by healthcare, academic firms and consumer stocks.
Miners and banks are also weighing on the market.
Gold miner Bellevue Gold (+2.8 per cent) is doing the best, while artificial intelligence firm BrainChip Holdings (-3.6 per cent) is having another bad day.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Three years ago today Rio Tinto destroyed 46,000 year old sacred caves at Juukan Gorge in the Pilbara to mine iron ore. The events of May 24, 2020, triggered a Senate inquiry, forced three Rio Tinto executives to resign including former chief executive Jean Sebastian-Jacques, and saw Western Australia update its cultural heritage law. In the wake of the incident, the Federal Government will draft new national heritage laws to increase protections for Indigenous sacred sites and review native title legislation. Rio Tinto is working with the Juukan Gorge traditional owners, the Puutu Kunti Kurrama people (PKKP) to rehabilitate the site. But traditional owner Burchell Hayes says that will never make up for the destruction. "The destruction of our most significant cultural heritage site should not have happened, and to ensure that we will never experience this senseless feeling of loss and devastation in the future, we are driven towards achieving a co-management process of country with mining companies." "We have already started to see minor aspects of the co-management model working at Juukan Gorge, though rehabilitation works of some of the surrounding areas." “Overall, we are pleased with the rehabilitation and remediation works that have since occurred  through the committee’s instructions and directions, but in saying this, nothing will make up for the  destruction at Juukan Gorge." Here's more on the fallout from the destruction of the Juukan Gorge caves from my colleagues in the ABC's Indigenous Reporting Team.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Traditional owners mark Juukan Gorge destruction

featuredLink.title: 'Inconceivable': Inquiry says Australia needs new laws to avoid another Juukan Gorge disaster

children.content: Three years ago today Rio Tinto destroyed 46,000 year old sacred caves at Juukan Gorge in the Pilbara to mine iron ore.

The events of May 24, 2020, triggered a Senate inquiry, forced three Rio Tinto executives to resign including former chief executive Jean Sebastian-Jacques, and saw Western Australia update its cultural heritage law.
In the wake of the incident, the Federal Government will draft new national heritage laws to increase protections for Indigenous sacred sites and review native title legislation.
Rio Tinto is working with the Juukan Gorge traditional owners, the Puutu Kunti Kurrama people (PKKP) to rehabilitate the site.
But traditional owner Burchell Hayes says that will never make up for the destruction.

"The destruction of our most significant cultural heritage site should not have happened, and to ensure that we will never experience this senseless feeling of loss and devastation in the future, we are driven towards achieving a co-management process of country with mining companies."
"We have already started to see minor aspects of the co-management model working at Juukan Gorge, though rehabilitation works of some of the surrounding areas."

“Overall, we are pleased with the rehabilitation and remediation works that have since occurred  through the committee’s instructions and directions, but in saying this, nothing will make up for the  destruction at Juukan Gorge."
Here's more on the fallout from the destruction of the Juukan Gorge caves from my colleagues in the ABC's Indigenous Reporting Team.

image.altText: Snowy troubles - Tunnel 2.0

items.synopsis: Following the revelation made by Dennis Barnes at a Senate estimates hearing, an analyst predicts the project cost will blow out to at least five times the original figure.

title.children: Snowy Hydro boss says boring machine could be stuck for 'weeks or months' as cost blowouts scrutinised
